G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, any order regarding custody or parenting time must serve the “best interests of the child.” See, e.g., G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 10; *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Confirm that the parties shall continue to share legal custody only to the extent that such shared legal custody remains in the child’s best interests and does not place the child at risk; and, if the Court finds that conflict or safety concerns render shared legal custody inappropriate, grant the Plaintiff sole legal custody pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 31;

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, any order regarding custody or parenting time must serve the “best interests of the child.” See, e.g., G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 10; *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the custody inquiry in terms of the child’s welfare and mandates explicit findings about how domestic violence affects the child when making custody and shared custody orders, tying this to existing statutory “best interest” language in G.L. c. 208, § 31. Although the case is more focused on the need to consider domestic violence specifically, its reasoning assumes and applies the overarching Massachusetts standard that custody and parenting arrangements must be evaluated based on their impact on the child’s well‑being. It therefore provides supportive authority, though not as a primary articulation, for the general best‑interests principle cited in the proposition.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt:
“The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. … The Appeals Court’s remand order is designed to do just that. We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that … a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm.”

…

“Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, any order regarding custody or parenting time must serve the “best interests of the child.” See, e.g., G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 10; *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly affirms that custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) are governed by the “best interests of the child” standard and discusses that standard as the longstanding and overarching test in Massachusetts custody matters. The court both describes the historical centrality of the best-interests test and applies it to uphold the custody and parenting-time order in this case, thus supporting the proposition that any custody/parenting-time order must serve the child’s best interests.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly … as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002) (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’).”

*Murphy v. Murphy*, 380 Mass. 454 (1980).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has held that a custody or parenting-time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. See, e.g., *Murphy v. Murphy*, 380 Mass. 454 (1980); *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
*Murphy v. Murphy*, 380 Mass. 454 (1980).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses modification of a foreign custody decree only briefly and in a different context: it notes that a party seeking modification of a foreign pendente lite decree must show a material change in circumstances, primarily in relation to whether Massachusetts should entertain simultaneous proceedings. It does not articulate or adopt the full two‑part standard claimed (material and substantial change plus necessity in the child’s best interests) for modifying an existing Massachusetts custody or parenting-time order. The case is focused on jurisdiction and forum selection, not on setting the substantive standard for modification of custody orders.
*Murphy v. Murphy*, 380 Mass. 454 (1980).relevant_excerpt:
The wife alleged no material change in circumstances since the time of that proceeding other than her illegal removal of the child.
...
The party seeking modification of a foreign custody decree is required to show a material change in circumstances. Buchanan v. Buchanan, 353 Mass. 351 (1967). See also G. L. c. 209, §§ 32, 37. This principle has particular relevance where the foreign decree is pendente lite, in light of the policy against entertaining a custody proceeding in Massachusetts at the same time a similar proceeding is pending in a competent court of a sister State.

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has held that a custody or parenting-time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. See, e.g., *Murphy v. Murphy*, 380 Mass. 454 (1980); *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The opinion in Yannas concerns initial custody determination and, primarily, removal of children from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30. It articulates the ‘real advantage’/best-interests standard for removal, not the standard for *modification* of an existing custody or parenting-time order based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. The court does not discuss or apply a ‘material and substantial change’ requirement for modifying prior orders, so it does not support the proposition as stated.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)….”}

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has held that a custody or parenting-time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the governing standard for modification of custody under G.L. c. 208, § 28: there must be a material and substantial change in circumstances and the modification must be necessary in the best interests of the child. The court both quotes the statutory language and applies it, holding that no such material and substantial change occurred here. That aligns directly with the proposition for which Rosenthal is cited.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.raw_text: *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (1983) (child’s welfare is paramount consideration)
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.proposition: Continued unsupervised or unrestricted overnight parenting time where a parent is allegedly abusing alcohol or other intoxicants and appears impaired in the direct care of the child is inconsistent with the child’s best interests and may expose the child to risk of physical and emotional harm. See, e.g., *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (1983) (child’s welfare is paramount consideration); *Adoption of New England*, 364 Mass. 835 (1973).
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses general standards for custody, emphasizing parental fitness, the best interests of the child, and that the child’s welfare governs over parental rights. It does not address parenting time, visitation, or the specific issue of unsupervised or overnight contact where a parent abuses alcohol or intoxicants, nor any related risk analysis. Thus, while it supports the broad idea that the child’s welfare is paramount, it does not provide authority for the more specific proposition concerning impaired parenting time due to substance abuse.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.relevant_excerpt: “However, the parents’ right to custody is not absolute, and it must yield to the welfare of the child. … ‘State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.’ … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’”

*Adoption of New England*, 364 Mass. 835.proposition: Continued unsupervised or unrestricted overnight parenting time where a parent is allegedly abusing alcohol or other intoxicants and appears impaired in the direct care of the child is inconsistent with the child’s best interests and may expose the child to risk of physical and emotional harm. See, e.g., *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (1983) (child’s welfare is paramount consideration); *Adoption of New England*, 364 Mass. 835 (1973).
*Adoption of New England*, 364 Mass. 835.case_name: Jenkins v. Guardianship Administrator, Illinois Department of Children & Family Services
*Adoption of New England*, 364 Mass. 835.support_reasoning: The opinion in Adoption of New England is a short procedural decision about mootness and vacating a decree to avoid collateral estoppel effects. It does not discuss parental alcohol or substance abuse, overnight parenting time, or the substantive best-interests standard. It therefore provides no authority for the proposition about unsupervised parenting time where a parent appears impaired by intoxicants.
*Adoption of New England*, 364 Mass. 835.relevant_excerpt: "As counsel for the petitioner suggested, she 'should be free of collateral estoppel consequences ... if any issues of fact or law determined by the judge below should perchance reappear in future litigation between the parties.' Reilly v. School Comm. of Boston, 362 Mass. 689, 696 (1972). We therefore vacate the decree appealed from with a notation that the decision is not on the merits, and remand the case to the Probate Court with directions to dismiss the petition as moot."

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Bouchard upheld limitations on visitation where necessary for the child’s best interests, but the excerpted opinion does not discuss visitation at all, much less uphold limitations on it. Instead, the Appeals Court reverses a custody award and reiterates that all relevant factors must be weighed and that the welfare of the child is the paramount consideration. While the case does support the broader best-interests principle, it is mis-cited for a specific holding about visitation limits.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied). … This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

*Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly emphasized the paramount importance of a child’s safety and stability in custody determinations. See, e.g., *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. at 595–96 (1996) (court must protect child from potential harm); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (rescript op.) (upholding limitations on visitation where necessary for child’s best interests); *Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232 (1981) (deferring to trial court’s assessment of child’s welfare and need for protective conditions).
*Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: The proposition claims Felton as authority that Massachusetts courts emphasize the paramount importance of a child’s safety and stability in custody determinations and that Felton defers to the trial court’s assessment of the child’s welfare and need for protective conditions. In fact, Felton reverses the Probate Court’s restrictive visitation order for lack of evidence of harm and expressly finds “clear error” in the judge’s conclusions about a “deleterious effect.” The opinion does discuss the ‘best interests’ standard and the need to avert harm, but it does not defer to the trial judge’s assessment here and instead corrects it, so it does not support the proposition in the manner cited.
*Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “However, harm to the child from conflicting religious instructions or practices, which would justify such a limitation, should not be simply assumed or surmised; it must be demonstrated in detail… The decisions hold such an infirmity to be fatal to an action seeking to limit materially or to cancel visitation rights… Thus there is clear error, for lack of foundation in the record, in the judge’s findings of a ‘deleterious effect’ on the children and an ‘undermining’ of the custodial relationship by reason of the father’s religious instruction or practice.”

*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.raw_text: *Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392 Mass. 704 (1984) (court may impose conditions to protect children)
*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.proposition: Where substance use or impairment by a parent during parenting time is credibly raised, the Court may impose appropriate safeguards, including supervision, conditions on visitation, or other protective orders, to ensure the child’s safety. See *Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392 Mass. 704 (1984) (court may impose conditions to protect children); *Adoption of Carlos*, 413 Mass. 339 (1992) (substance abuse relevant to parental fitness and child’s welfare).
*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with care and protection commitments, parental unfitness, and the need for detailed dispositional orders guiding placement and visitation. It does not address substance use or impairment by a parent, nor does it discuss imposing safeguards such as supervised or conditioned visitation in response to substance abuse. While it recognizes that a judge may issue more detailed orders concerning custody and visitation to protect children, it is not authority for the specific proposition about substance-related safeguards during parenting time.
*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.relevant_excerpt: “Although a simple commitment order is all that is required by G. L. c. 119, § 26… in this case, the judge should have given the department some guidance regarding the ultimate placement of the children and visitation by family members…. Even if the separation of Mary from her sisters and grandparents is ultimately found to be in her best interests, some direction from the judge regarding continued visitation is required…. the judge must include in his order some direction to the department that visitation shall continue or make findings that support his conclusion if he believes it should not.”

*Adoption of Carlos*, 413 Mass. 339 (199.raw_text: *Adoption of Carlos*, 413 Mass. 339 (1992) (substance abuse relevant to parental fitness and child’s welfare)
*Adoption of Carlos*, 413 Mass. 339 (199.proposition: Where substance use or impairment by a parent during parenting time is credibly raised, the Court may impose appropriate safeguards, including supervision, conditions on visitation, or other protective orders, to ensure the child’s safety. See *Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392 Mass. 704 (1984) (court may impose conditions to protect children); *Adoption of Carlos*, 413 Mass. 339 (1992) (substance abuse relevant to parental fitness and child’s welfare).
*Adoption of Carlos*, 413 Mass. 339 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion in Adoption of Carlos concerns termination of parental rights, parental unfitness, and the weighing of present versus future fitness in deciding whether to dispense with consent to adoption. It does not address parental substance use, impairment during parenting time, or the court’s authority to impose supervised or conditional visitation or other protective orders based on such impairment. The case is therefore not authority for the specific proposition about safeguards in response to substance use during parenting time.
*Adoption of Carlos*, 413 Mass. 339 (199.relevant_excerpt: A parent’s right to the custody of his or her child may not be terminated under the care and protection statute, G. L. c. 119, §§ 21-39 (1990 ed.), or the adoption statute, G. L. c. 210, § 3 (1990 ed.), without clear and convincing evidence that the parent is currently unfit to further the child’s best interest. Furthermore, parental fitness and the best interests of the child are interrelated factors.

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 368.proposition: The “material and substantial change in circumstances” standard is satisfied when new facts arise that were not and could not reasonably have been anticipated at the time of the prior judgment, and which affect the child’s welfare. See *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 368–69 (1981); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261–63 (2001).
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 368.support_reasoning: The opinion applies the general Massachusetts rule that a movant must show a “material change of circumstances” to modify alimony or child support, but it does not elaborate that this requires ‘new facts that were not and could not reasonably have been anticipated’ or that specifically ‘affect the child’s welfare.’ Instead, it treats change in circumstances broadly, focusing on the payor’s income, earning capacity, and assets and ultimately finding no sufficient change. The specific anticipation/child-welfare gloss in the proposition comes from later or different authorities, not from Schuler itself.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 368.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The “material and substantial change in circumstances” standard is satisfied when new facts arise that were not and could not reasonably have been anticipated at the time of the prior judgment, and which affect the child’s welfare. See *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 368–69 (1981); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261–63 (2001).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Rosenthal clearly applies and restates the statutory standard that a modification of custody requires a “material and substantial change in circumstances” since the prior judgment and that the change must warrant modification in the child’s best interests. However, the opinion does not articulate the more specific gloss that the change must consist of “new facts that were not and could not reasonably have been anticipated at the time of the prior judgment.” That unanticipated‑facts language comes from other cases (e.g., Schuler), not from Rosenthal itself, so citing Rosenthal for that particular formulation overstates what this opinion holds.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’ Tolos v. Tolos, 11 Mass. App. Ct. 708, 710-711 (1981) (citation omitted).”}

*Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882 (19.proposition: Substance abuse or impairment by a parent is a relevant and significant factor in assessing parental fitness and the safety and stability of the child’s environment. See *Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392 Mass. 704 (1984); *Adoption of Carlos*, 413 Mass. 339 (1992); *Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882 (1997).
*Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion affirms a finding of parental unfitness based in part on the father’s drug use, specifically that he used the mother’s public assistance funds to purchase drugs, and on the resulting inability of the parents to provide a safe and stable environment. While the decision’s primary focus is broader neglect and instability, substance abuse is expressly identified and relied on as one of the significant factors supporting unfitness. The case thus treats parental drug use as a relevant component of the parental fitness and child-welfare analysis, though it is not discussed at length as a standalone doctrinal point.
*Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882 (19.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that there was adequate evidence to support the findings that: the parents maintained an unsafe and unsanitary home and failed to take steps to correct these conditions; the parents lived an itinerant lifestyle which was harmful to the children; they neglected the emotional well-being of the children; the father never displayed a long-term commitment to stay with the family; **the father used the public assistance funds to purchase drugs;** the mother lacked the ability to protect the children from the father’s harmful conduct; and the mother lacked the capacity to deal with the needs of the children.
